title: Quarto Course Notes
text:
This is the Quarto Book!
Rendered via:
quarto render --profile book

title: 1  Setup Justification
text:
1.1 Slides-first mentality
_quarto.yml assumes that the format is going to be beamer slides. This is because I use VSCode to make my slides, and Cmd-Shift-K will build according to the _quarto.yml file. This means I prototype my notes as slides, then just kinda assume that the book will look good.
The _quarto-book.yml has a special name. The -book part tells quarto that it’s part of the “Book” project.

title: 1  Setup Justification
text:
1.2 Rendering the Book
quarto render --profile book
Alternately,
quarto preview --profile book

title: 1  Setup Justification

title: 1  Setup Justification
text:
1.4 Publishing on GitHub
The _quarto-book.yml file puts the book in the “docs” folder, which is a required name! GitHub allows you to serve a static site from the docs page.

title: 2  Some advanced things
text:
2.1 ShinyLive
Shiny Live allows shiny apps to be run from within the book - without storing the book on a shiny server!
Every time the user opens your book, the shiny app installs all of the required packages. For best results, keep packages to a minimum.
(This repo does not have an example because the extension adds dependencies. I’ll maybe make another repo just to outline the steps I needed to take.)

title: 2  Some advanced things
text:
2.2 Quizzes for your LMS
In my slides, I include something like:
## Q1

Which of the following statements is *False*?

a. True
b. False

<!--- B --->
I use a custom R script to find a string like the last one, and it extracts the answer and makes a question that can be uploaded to my LMS. The questions are just of the format “Q1: A, B, C, or D?”, so the students answer in the LMS but only see the actual questions on the slides. This is specific to the way I do things, but it has saved quite a bit of time and lets me do quizzes tied to their student numbers without an external tool.
